message: Short sleep can dampen serotonin pathways and mood balance.
action: Take a 10–20 min sunlight walk.
why: Morning light steadies the serotonin cycle that sleep debt blunts.

message: A recent dip in mood can signal dopamine systems cooling after stress.
action: Complete a 2‑min quick-win task.
why: Tiny completions nudge dopamine back online after stress hangovers.

message: Body clock may be drifting later, nudging cortisol and melatonin out of sync.
action: Get morning light; skip caffeine after 2pm.
why: Mid-sleep has shifted later than usual, hinting at circadian slip.

message: Lower movement can reduce endorphins that buffer low mood.
action: Take a 5–10 min brisk walk.
why: Movement refreshes beta-endorphins that lift and stabilise mood.

message: Missed doses can lessen steady-state medication effects.
action: Tie your next dose to a daily habit.
why: Consistent timing keeps therapeutic levels smooth and predictable.

message: Long sleep can leave adenosine lingering and energy feeling flat.
action: Splash cool water and get 3 min outdoor light.
why: Extra-long sleep plus low energy hints at residual sleep inertia.

message: Mood tends to steady when social oxytocin circuits get gentle activation.
action: Send a short check-in text.
why: A few low-social days during a mood dip—time for a quick reach-out.

message: Stress plus short sleep can nudge vagal tone down and heart rate up.
action: Try 3 rounds of 4-7-8 breathing.
why: Parasympathetic reset helps counter short sleep + stress pairing.

message: High consistency keeps routines predictable.
action: Guard the next dose time the same way you have this week.
why: For many meds, steady timing reduces variability; your current anchor is working—keep it.

message: Minor drift—make timing more predictable.
action: Tie one dose today to a fixed habit to cut decision fatigue.
why: For many meds, anchoring a single dose to a reliable cue smooths timing variability.

message: Rebuilding consistency starts with the next dose.
action: Pick the next time now; keep it simple and repeatable.
why: For many meds, reducing variability comes from one repeatable anchor—start with the very next dose.

message: Small inputs → better insights.
action: Log a quick check-in to keep your patterns clear.
why: When nothing specific pops, the best next step is a tiny check-in.

message: Low mood often feels like energy conservation in the brain’s motivation chemistry.
action: Log a 1-line note: what happened in the last hour?
why: When drive dips, noting recent events helps your brain reallocate effort toward small steps.

message: Mood is below your recent baseline; stress systems may be pulling chemistry downward.
action: Do a 2-minute reset (water + light movement).
why: Tiny resets can rebalance effort and serotonin/dopamine signals without forcing big changes.

message: Mood is above baseline—your brain is tagging this window as working.
action: Mark what helped (add a tag) to repeat later.
why: Reinforcing what lifted mood strengthens the pattern your brain uses to predict good days.

message: Mood trend is dipping; accumulating load can nudge cortisol/stress balance.
action: Protect one recovery block tonight.
why: A small, predictable recovery block helps your system rebalance after a downtrend.

message: Mood trend is rising—momentum builds expectation and chemistry.
action: Keep the same anchor habit tomorrow.
why: Repeating the habit that preceded an uptrend reinforces the brain’s “this works” signal.

message: Stress signals are up; sympathetic drive can crowd out calm focus.
action: Try 60 seconds of slow exhale breathing.
why: Long exhales help downshift sympathetic activation and ease tension.

message: A week without social touchpoints can reduce natural buffering.
action: Send one low-effort message.
why: Light social contact often helps regulate mood by easing threat scanning.

message: A few days without contact can leave mood feeling flat.
action: Plan a small touchpoint.
why: Even brief connection can lift mood by engaging social regulation pathways.

message: Feeling tired can reflect rising sleep pressure.
action: If possible, take 10 minutes of daylight or a short walk.
why: Light movement and daylight can ease adenosine build-up and lift alertness.

message: No tags yet—tagging helps spot what shifts mood.
action: Add one tag on your next check-in.
why: Tagging gives your brain a clearer pattern to repeat or adjust.

message: Small mood check-ins train your pattern detector.
action: Log today’s mood with one tag.
why: More check-ins make mood patterns clearer and insights more relevant.
